title.narrative: Emergency response to support Rohingya refugees 2020

description.narrative:
At the end of August 2017, state-tolerated acts of violence by the military in Rakhine State in Myanmar forced more than 700,000 Rohingya to flee to Bangladesh. They joined the approximately 250,000 Rohingya who had already fled the country in previous refugee waves. This means that more than 914,000 Rohingya are living now in overcrowded refugee camps in Cox's Bazaar district in Bangladesh and are completely dependent on humanitarian aid.
The Kutupalong Expansion Site alone hosts 613,270 refugees making it the largest and most densely populated refugee settlement in the world. Two years later, the situation of refugees continues to be characterized by chronic under-funding and lengthy approval and coordination processes on the ground, which hampered the delivery of humanitarian aid to those affected in a timely, effective and appropriate manner. People's needs remain high in all sectors. Safer and more durable shelters, which offer better protection against extreme weather, as well as educational and employment opportunities, are priority concerns for the refugees, but continue to be subject to very restrictive government regulations.
This project builds upon CAFOD's previous projects with Caritas Bangladesh and aims to support 3200 families (14,720 people) with site/camp improvements and shelter repairs.
